metadata.videoTitle: How to Improve Oral Health & Its Critical Role in Brain & Body Health

title: Proper Flossing Technique, Waterpik; Children & Flossing

paragraphList.text: Proper oral hygiene, including the practice of flossing, is crucial for maintaining good dental health. While there may be some debate within the dentistry field regarding the effectiveness of flossing, the consensus among most dentists is that flossing is an essential component of oral care. It is important to floss correctly to ensure maximum benefits for your teeth and gums. Pulling the floss down onto the gum between the teeth is not the correct technique. Instead, it is recommended to glide the floss down the side of the tooth, get beneath the gum line, use a circular motion, and then lift the floss up from between the teeth. This method may be easier for individuals whose teeth are not very close together.

Dentists emphasize the importance of flossing correctly, especially if your gums bleed during the process. In such cases, bleeding gums may indicate the need for more consistent and proper flossing. It is advised to floss at least twice a day between all teeth. Flossing once a day, ideally at night before sleeping, is crucial for removing food particles and plaque buildup that can lead to dental issues.

While traditional floss works well for most people, some dentists recommend using a water flosser, like a Waterpik, as an alternative. Water flossers are considered gentler on the teeth and gums and can be as efficient as standard flossing. They are an appealing option for those looking for a more comfortable and effective flossing experience. However, using traditional dental floss remains a low-cost and straightforward method for maintaining oral health for the majority of individuals.

When it comes to children and flossing, the approach may vary. Children under the age of six, who often have larger spaces between their baby teeth, may not need to floss between those teeth. These spaces serve to allow room for adult teeth to come in properly. For children with significant spaces between their teeth, flossing between them may not be necessary and could potentially cause harm to their gums. It is important to consult with a pediatric dentist to determine the best oral care practices for children, taking into consideration their specific dental needs and development stage.
